info.latinDescription: Officially adopted on September 2, 1993, by the decree of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan.
info.latinItem1: 29 letters: A, B, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, X, Y, Z, O', G', Sh, Ch, Ng
info.latinItem2: Complies with international standards, convenient for computer typing
info.latinItem3: Since 2021, all official documents are only in Latin script
info.cyrillicDescription: Writing system used during the Soviet Union period between 1940-1992.
info.cyrillicItem1: 35 letters: А, Б, В, Г, Д, Е, Ё, Ж, З, И, Й, К, Л, М, Н, О, П, Р, С, Т, У, Ф, Х, Ц, Ч, Ш, Ъ, Ь, Э, Ю, Я, Ў, Қ, Ғ, Ҳ
info.cyrillicItem2: Similar to Russian, many literary works are in this script
info.cyrillicItem3: Currently found in archival documents and classical literature
info.historyDescription: Uzbek writing changed 4 times in 100 years: Arabic, Latin, Cyrillic, and Latin again.
info.usageDescription: Both alphabets are actively used in various fields and have their own significance.
info.usageItem1: Latin: Education, government documents, internet, business
info.usageItem2: Cyrillic: Classical literature, archives, older generation
info.featuresDescription: Professional conversion tool developed based on modern technologies.
info.featuresItem2: Fast processing - large texts in seconds
info.featuresItem3: File upload - supports PDF, DOCX, TXT formats
info.statisticsDescription: Interesting numbers and facts about the Uzbek language and alphabets.
info.statisticsItem2: 95% of Uzbekistan's population knows Latin script
info.statisticsItem3: 10,000+ books published annually in Latin script
